posts.name: MR.L
posts.cooked:
I can compile normally on my Mac OS X. but Fedora34 cannot be compiled.

posts.name: MR.L
posts.cooked: At this time my cmake version： cmake version 3.20.5 gcc (GCC) 11.2.1 20210728 (Red Hat 11.2.1-1) ++ (GCC) 11.2.1 20210728 (Red Hat 11.2.1-1)

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked:
If you insist on using the old release version then perhaps you should also match it with the GCC and CMake version that were available at the time it was being released. However, just for a long shot, you could try to disable the Precompiled Header for the Urho3D library building by disabling the “URHO3D_PCH” build option.

祝你好运

posts.name: MR.L
posts.cooked: Thanks!After turning off the URHO3D_PCH option, it can be compiled, but it cannot be linked. I want to know the version requirements of gcc g++ cmake.I use the source code of 1.7.1.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: You didn’t say what was the linker error. But in any case, you should always remember to nuke the build tree and recreate a new one to test, especially when you have changed the critical build options and/or attempted to install prerequisites dependency development packages as you go the first time round. The CMake cache is a double-edged sword.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked:
That’s the GCC 10 (and above) problem. It didn’t exist in the past. Since version 10 GCC has defaulted to “-fno-common”. In its release notes, it states it is the right thing to do even though knowingly the change will break some legacy code. To cut the story short, you need this patch from the main branch.

github.com/urho3d/Urho3D

Quick fix for Wayland with both GCC and Clang.

committed 03:41PM - 05 Aug 21 UTC
weitjong
+3 -0

link_counts.title: Quick fix for Wayland with both GCC and Clang. · urho3d/Urho3D@884c094 · GitHub

gmake[1]: *** [CMakeFiles/Makefile2:2382：Source/Urho3D/CMakeFiles/Urho3D.dir/all] 错误 2
gmake: *** [Makefile:156：all] 错误 2

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: Now this one is totally not expected. I have not encountered this before. Some how your build tree has generated a broken “script.ar” file. Search for that file and inspect its content. Try to invoke “ar” command with it. Do you have a space in your path or something? Or a path with Chinese character?

posts.name: MR.L
posts.cooked:
Cool! I run it successfully.

The problem is that my path has Chinese characters in it.

Thanks for you. I can use it to make my first game.

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: Glad to hear that. You should really use the main branch if you just start to make your game. There is no point to stick to the old release.

posts.name: Nicholas J Ingrassellino
posts.cooked:
Saw this page, reminded me of this thread.

New version of SDL2 released with “much improved Wayland support”.

link_counts.title: SDL version 2.0.16 is out now with much improved Wayland support | GamingOnLinux

posts.name: Yao Wei Tjong
posts.cooked: Yes, that’s the main reason why I am upgrading the Linux DBE with libdecor and Pipewire deps installed.
